Dear Sir:

We submit herewith report on the students of the Indian Reserve who attended our High School January 1st, 1946 to June 30th, 1946:

Brant, Lorraine was promoted from Grade 12 to 13. A good student who is often absent to help at home.

Greene, Phyllis was promoted to Grade 12 with a condition in Algebra. She is a hard working student and regular in attendance.

Greene, Eugene Left school in May and is working in Kingston. He was doing fair work in Grade 10.

Brant, Betty Left school in June as her mother was ill. She may return in the month of September if her mother's health improves. Grade 9.

Green, Smith An excellent student. Promoted to Grade 10.

Hennon, Freda An excellent student promoted to Grade 10.

Maracle, Cedrick Left school early to work on the farm. He may return in September. A clever boy who should be kept in school.

The above reports are of our principal, A.C. Reid, a copy of which we have on our files.

Yours very truly,

J.C. Reynolds.
Vice-Chairman
Board of Education.
Ottawa, August 12, 1946.

Mr. J. H. McVicker, In charge, Indian Agency Office,
Deseronto, Ontario.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing report from the Principal of Deseronto High School regarding the seven Indian children who were in attendance at that school during the academic year 1945-46.

In view of the fact that they were promoted to a higher grade, the Department will allow, for the academic year 1946-47, the same amount as previously, for the following:

1. Lorraine Brant;
2. Phyllis Greene;
3. Edith Green;
4. Freda Hannon.

With regard to Lorraine Brant, the Principal states that she is a good student but is often absent to help at home. I feel that you should interview her parents and request their full co-operation. If this girl is going to be successful in her school work, the parents should assist by having her attend school regularly.

Gedrick Maracle is stated to be a clever boy but is reported to have left school early to work on farm. Was he promoted to a higher form? Was it absolutely necessary for him to leave school early? It would appear that this is another case where the parents should be interviewed and urged to co-operate in the education of their son.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Deseronto, Ontario, September 13th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Please find enclosed application for tuition grant on behalf of Eva Green, thirteen year old daughter of No.717 - Abel Green of Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, who desires a tuition grant to allow her to attend Deseronto High School.

This girl formerly attended Eastern Indian Day School, and while quite capable academically, the teacher Miss Stoddart did not find her very co-operative, but, despite that she did pass her Entrance examination in June of this year. It is recommended that the Department grant the necessary authority for this girl to attend Deseronto High School for this coming term, and, if her attendance and marks do not warrant continuance, that the grant be discontinued.

J.H. McVicker,
Acting Indian Agent.
Deseronto, Ontario, September 13th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

This office is in receipt of an enquiry from Mrs. Frank Claus, No. 784 of the Mohawk Band of Tyendinaga Reserve, regarding tuition fees for her daughter Joan who wishes to attend the Ontario Business College at Belleville this term. Mrs. Claus states that she is not able financially to pay for this course, and would like to know if the Department would assume the cost. This family own a home on the reserve, which is rented, and have been resident in the City of Belleville for the past two years. I would wish to be advised if authority can be granted for the Department to assume this responsibility.

J.H. McVicker,
Acting Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 17 September 1946.

Mr. J.H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent,
DEBERONTO, Ontario.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant with reference to an application that you have received for payment of the tuition fees of Joan Claus. It is noted from your letter that this family has resided off the Reserve for the past two years. Under these circumstances the Department does not consider itself liable for payment of tuition fees and you should so inform the mother.

With reference to your second letter of September 13th, the Department will pay the usual tuition fees of the Deseronto High School to enable Eva Green to attend that school during the academic year 1946-47. It is understood that if her attendance and marks do not warrant the continuance of the grant after the end of the present term it will be discontinued.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Department
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

For the past two years I have been teaching in Shannonville Public School, and I find a situation there (since it promises to be no better this term) that I feel, in duty bound to report to you.

We have on our attendance roll a number of pupils from the Indian Reserve near by, under the agency of Mr. A.D. Moore. Some of these are regular in attendance and prove to be delightful pupils. Others due to home conditions, and parental neglect, have a most deplorable attendance record. There are three on our roll who have not even reported yet this term.

Each year I have reported this at regular intervals to the agent. I have contacted the doctor in charge. This fall I have even appealed to the Reserve Council, all to very little effect.

In all due justice to these
children themselves, and to the unfairness of the condition to our school grants. I feel that steps should be taken to correct matters as far as possible.

Should the department wish names and particulars I shall be glad to supply them. Perhaps if a representative of the Mounted Police would call at the school for details, and visit the homes it might have some result.

Yours truly,

(Mrs) Hazel A. Holden.

167 Dundas W.
Belleville, Ont.
Ottawa, 26 October 1946.

Mr. J.H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent,
DESERONTO, Ontario.

Indian Students attending Shannonville Public School, Belleville, Ont.

The attached letter has been received from Mrs. Hazel A. Holden, 167 Dundas West, Belleville, concerning the attendance of certain Indian children at this school.

Could you please ascertain the names of the children whose attendance has been irregular and take what action concerning them that you deem necessary under the circumstances?

We wish a report submitted on the attendance for September and October of all children at this school for whom the Department is paying the tuition fees. As you are aware, family allowances to Indian parents are stopped where children are absent from school without sufficient cause for five days in any academic month.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, October 28, 1946.

EX'D.

Dear Mrs. Holden:

I have for answer your letter of October 23 concerning the poor attendance of certain Indian children at the Shannonville Public School. I have written to Mr. J. H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent at Deseronto, asking for a report on the attendance of these children. You will no doubt be hearing from him further in this regard.

Mr. Moore has been seriously ill and Mr. McVicker has been acting in his stead. He is probably unaware of the situation as revealed in your letter and it is hoped that the attendance of these children can be improved as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. Hazel Holden,
167 Dundas Street,
Belleville, Ontario.

Gentlemen:

The Dept. of Education for Ontario requires that you give an approval for the Education of Joan Brant a resident of Tyendinaga Indian Reserve as a student at the Belleville Collegiate Institute before they give any consideration to payment of the cost of Education of this child as a Non-Resident pupil.

While the amount involved is trivial, we would be glad to have the matter cleared and would appreciate having such a statement of approval.

Yours sincerely,

L. A. Kelso
Secretary.
Ottawa, 4 November 1946.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to Joan Brant. It is presumed that you refer to an account of $6.87 which was forwarded to Mr. A.D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ontario.

Joan Brant was sent to the Belleville Collegiate by her parents without any authority either from the Indian office at Deseronto or from this Department.

We are informed that she only attended for a period of one month.

If the Indian Affairs Branch is required to pay tuition fees for Indian children at High Schools and Collegiate Institutes, it is understood by both Indian parents and officials in the field that the approval of this office must first be obtained. Joan Brant's parents did not request the necessary authority and consequently we do not consider that we are responsible for payment of her fees.

It is felt that you will realize that unless we first approve of any expenditure, it is simply impossible for us to control our appropriation.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. L.A. Kells, Secretary,
Board of Education,

Mr. J.H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent,
DESERONTO, Ontario.

Enclosed is a letter received from Mrs. Frank Claus. You wrote us regarding this woman's daughter under cover of your letter of Sept. 13 and we replied on Sept. 17.

In view of the contents of the enclosed letter, you may consider it advisable to make a further recommendation. When replying, you might let us know what rent the family obtains for the house they own on the reserve. Is this woman's husband in a Mental Hospital and if so, is the Department paying for his maintenance?

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir,

I wrote the Indian Agent of Orono asking if the Department of Mines and Resources would pay for my daughter's education at business college, and came back saying we have lived off the Indian Reserve too long.

I would like to remind you, my husband is mentally ill, in hospital at Kingston, and has been for some time. When my husband went to the hospital I had to
go to work. It was necessary that I move to the city as I had no way of getting to and from work. I did not move from the Reserve because I wanted to and my daughter is still a member of the Mohawk Indians therefore I am not asking for something that she has no right to. I know there is money set aside for the education of every Indian child. I am asking for something that belongs to my child, her right to get an education. I have no income, only
what I earn, working myself
and that is not enough to
send my daughter to school.
Her fees were paid at
High school and we were
not living on the Indian
Reserve. I want my daughter
to have an education and
is it possible to have her
fees paid, for the eight months
at Bemus College.

Yours Truly

Mrs. Frank L. Davis.
106 Station Street.
Belleville.
Ont.
Deseronto, Ontario, November 30th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I would acknowledge your letter of November 13th in which you enclosed a communication received by you from Mrs. Frank Claus, regarding the tuition of her daughter at the Ontario Business College, Belleville. I would advise you that this woman has a house and fifty acres of land on the Tyendinaga Reserve for which she receives a yearly rental of $125.00. Her husband is in a Mental Hospital and is maintained there by payment from Band Funds. Mrs. Claus, in order to maintain her home, was forced to secure employment, and for that reason did take up residence in the city of Belleville. The tuition fee for her daughter at High School was paid by the Department.

The daughter Joan, who is 17 years of age, is an exceptionally smart girl and has completed her High School Course and is now very desirous of taking the Secretarial Course at the Ontario Business College. The total cost of this course, including the cost of books, is $130.00., and I would recommend that the Department assume this cost as the Mother is dependant on her own earnings to maintain her home and child.

The Letter received by you from Mrs. Frank Claus, is enclosed.

J.H. McVicker,
Acting Indian Agent.

JHMcV/MBF.
Ottawa, 4 December 1946.

Mr. J.H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent,
DESERONTO, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to Joan Claus.

You stated that she has completed her High School course. Please communicate with her mother and obtain a certificate from the principal of the High School or Collegiate Institute which she attended. This certificate should show exactly the grade which she attained.

When this is received, we will give further consideration to her request for a grant to take a course at the Ontario Business College.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Deseronto, Ontario, December 24th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Your letter of December 4th requesting the Certificate of Joan Claus to show which grade she did attain in High School is hereby acknowledged, and I herewith enclose this certificate which has this day been received here. I would request that this certificate be returned to Mrs. Frank Claus at 106, Station Street, Belleville, Ontario.

J.H. McVicker,
Acting Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 28, 1946.

Mr. J.H. McVicker, Acting Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.,

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant and previous correspondence regarding Joan Claus, it has been decided to allow an amount of $130.00 to enable her to take a course at the Ontario Business College. When payments of this grant are required application for same should be made by your office. Enclosed is the certificate which you forwarded with your letter.

Bernard E. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

We have a letter from Miss Verna Maracle who states she is attending Peterborough Normal School.

It appears from her letter that she is interested in obtaining an appointment as teacher at an Indian day school. We do not appear to be allowing her any tuition grant. Please let me know if she is a member of the Tyendinaga Band and any other information that you may have regarding her.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of April 16th, your file 103-34 (WT 1) regarding Miss Verna Maracle at present attending Peterborough Normal School and would inform you that she is the daughter of Mark Maracle, No. 645 on the Roll of the Mohawk Band.

As Mark Maracle has been resident in the town of Deseronto some fifteen years or more and owns his own home in the municipality his children have attended the local white schools and the cost of their education would be no responsibility of the Department.

Verna Maracle is twenty years of age with a very good scholastic record and last year won the award as the most outstanding pupil of the senior class of the Deseronto High School. She visited this office with the view of obtaining the position as teacher of one of the Reserve schools but as we could not give her any guarantee of the minimum salary as set out by the Teachers' Federation we advised her to write direct to the Department. This office is of the opinion that her initial efforts as teacher would meet with better success if she were teaching at a school on another reserve and not where she would have so many relatives and so forth.

J. H. McVicker,
Clerk in Charge.
Ottawa, April 24th, 1947.

Dear Miss Maracle:-

We have your letter of the 8th instant applying for appointment as teacher in an Indian day school. It is noted that you are attending Peterborough Normal School and we hope that you will be successful.

Enclosed is one of our regular application forms which you should complete and return. A new salary schedule goes into effect on September 1st, 1947 and is based on the experience and qualifications of the applicant. More detailed information regarding this salary schedule will be forwarded to you shortly.

At the present time I am not in a position to state what school you could be assigned, but I feel certain that we will be able to use your services.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard P. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Miss Verna Maracle,
P.O. Box 267,
Deseronto, Ontario.

Re: Western Day School (closed).

For the past two academic years the Western School on the Tyendinaga Reserve has been closed and the pupils who formerly attended that school have been going to the white schools at Shannonville and Milltown which are in close proximity to the Reserve.

A survey has been made of the parents who send their children to the white schools and with one exception they favour the idea to continue sending their children to these schools in preference to the Indian school, the exception being one family who live on the adjoining farm to the Western School property. The center of population of school children remains close to the white schools which is much less in distance to attend than the Indian school and I favour the idea to let Western school remain closed for another year at least and pay the Tyendinaga Township school board $2.00 a pupil per month for the Indian children attending Shannonville and Milltown schools.

This procedure is recommended for your approval and from the present enrollment it would mean paying for 25 pupils, a cost of $50.00 a month or $500.00 for the academic year which would be much less cost than re-opening Western School for the very few pupils that would attend there on account of distance and also the uncertainty of getting a fully qualified teacher for Western school which school is badly located for accommodation for a teacher and also for the Indian population of the Western end of the Reserve.

ADM/JMcV

It has been suggested that a building be secured at Deseronto Airport if and when they are declared surplus, and that a two-room school be erected to replace the present Central and Mission Schools. I am of the opinion there are sufficient children between the ages of six - sixteen to warrant a three-room school. Inasmuch as at the present time no children under seven can be admitted to the Mission School, which is the most heavily populated in the District, there will be children starting in September, who are almost eight years of age. The inauguration of a two or three-room school will involve some arrangements for transportation and it would be an easy matter to absorb some of the children who are at present time attending Eastern School, and bring the potential number up to between one hundred and one hundred and ten. There are also besides this, a number of non-Indian children residing on leased land and who have to go to Deseronto Public School. I think these could be included on the same basis of payment as we have with Indian children attending Public Schools.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Att'n Col. B.F. Henry

Reference your letter of February 23rd, file 32-34-3(E.1) in which you allow the amount of $10.00 per month for tuition for each of the two Loft boys attending Belleville Collegiate Institute.

I note that according to the Statement of Claim (see our Voucher No. 101, for cost of Education submitted by the Belleville Board of Education to our Department, for the year 1948) the amount charged for tuition is based on the ratio of attendance to the total cost, less any Provincial Grant. While the amount of $10.00 per month which you have allowed would be sufficient for 1948, there is a little doubt as to whether it will cover the cost during the year 1949 (According to the Administrator of the Belleville Board of Education, who informed me in a telephone conversation that the $10.00 would not be sufficient).

As I see it this leaves several alternatives; first, when the Belleville Board of Education bills us, we request the Department to authorize a supplementary amount; or second, that we assess the parents of the pupils with the difference between the cost and your authorized allowance of $10.00 per month; third, that you amend your instructions to cover this exigency.

I respectfully submit that this problem will arise also with our pupils attending Deseronto High School, and that to be fair to all concerned we should allow a tuition grant based on the cost of Education.

D.R.Cassie
Superintendent
Tyendinaga Agency
16th March, 1949.

Mr. D.R. Cassie,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Deseronto, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 2nd instant regarding the tuition grant which we promised to allow for each of the two Loft boys who are attending Belleville Collegiate Institute.

If the amount of the fees at the Collegiate should exceed $10.00 per month, during the period 1st January to 30th June, 1949, the Department will pay the extra amount.

At the end of June you should obtain a report from Belleville Collegiate regarding the progress of these boys and submit same to this office. We will require such a report before consideration can be given to allowing a tuition grant for these boys for the academic year 1949-50.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Att'n Col. B.F. Neary

Enclosed please find our Voucher No. 106 covering transportation for six pupils from the edge of the Reserve to Belleville Collegiate Institute. Only recently was I informed of these services being rendered. I understand this bus service commenced on the 1st of February 1949, and our pupils have been taking advantage of it without permission of this Office. These pupils formerly were going to Belleville in private cars with factory workers leaving before 7 A.M. and returning about 6 P.M.

If you see fit to authorize payment of this transportation, I think that for the present charge of 50¢ per pupil per day, the Driver should pick these pupils up on the Reserve as near their homes as possible. At the present time the parents of the children concerned are driving to Shannonville, which is at the edge of the reserve.

Further if transportation is provided for the six children, there is one other boy going to Belleville who should be provided with the same services.

D.R.Cassie,
Supt. Tyendinaga Agency.
28th March, 1949.

Mr. D.R. Cassie,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Deseronto, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 19th instant with reference to transportation of children from the Tyendinaga Reserve who are attending Belleville Collegiate Institute.

The parents made this arrangement without consulting the Department, and we feel that if we allowed half of the amount of the transportation it should be sufficient. As you are aware, we have already agreed to pay the tuition fees and the cost of books.

You should, therefore, amend your Voucher by requesting $30.00 a month instead of $60.00, from 1st February to 30th June, 1949. The bus driver should be fully informed that the parents concerned are responsible for the balance.

Bernard F. Neary,

Chief, Education Division
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Ont.

Reference your letter file 42034-3(E1) of August 30th, returning application for Tuition Grant for Donald Ray Brant.

Please be advised that I cannot answer item 9 as the amount will not be fully determined until early in 1951. As you are probably aware the Ontario Schools work on a Calendar year basis as far as finances are concerned. The cost per pupil is therefore not determined until the next calendar year. According to my present information, see our Voucher No. 101, Feb. 24/49, the cost of education for the year 1949 at Belleville School will be approximately .55¢ per day. As I do not know yet what the cost will be in 1950, I have put in the same figure in item 9.

Item 10, the parents will provide board for the child and half the transportation cost if the bus is used, or all the transportation cost if no bus is available.

Item 11 Indian Affairs Branch should therefore be requested to provide tuition grant plus half the cost of bus transportation if available.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sirs:

Please allow me to express my word of appreciation
for the financial assistance given me by the Department while
I was attending Collegiate and Technical school in Sarnia.

That assistance is largely responsible for the
success I am now having. I am now employed by the Chrysler
Corporation in the drafting, designing, engineering depart-
ment in Detroit, Mich.

After graduating from the Sarnia Collegiate and
Technical School, I began to work with the intention of
saving enough money to pay for my tuition at the Detroit
College of Applied Science. I worked and studied alter-
nately, and managed to complete a course in drafting,
designing and engineering.

I am following up that work now with every
intention of advancing my position.

I hope that similar aid will be given to those
pupils that show some ability.

Once again I thank those associated with the
Department for their part in enabling my plans to mater-
ialize.

Yours truly,

Charles Jacobs Jr.

Walpole Island, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In connection with your letter dated October 26 regarding Parker Pinmanse, this question has been referred to the Board of Education. The members have asked me to write you accordingly as follows:

The principal of the Chatham Vocational School accepted this pupil in good faith believing that Lambton County would pay for the cost of his education as for the other pupils. This Indian pupil has received the school services and someone has to pay for the cost.

It would certainly not be equitable to expect the taxpayers of the City of Chatham to pay the cost of education of an Indian boy from Walpole Island. It is on a par with a child buying groceries from the store, the groceries being consumed at home, and the parents declining to pay the bill. Furthermore, it would appear that the non-payment of such a bill would indicate the Indian child as being discriminated against.

Surely when an Indian boy wants to obtain secondary education he should be afforded the same facilities as his white brothers. It is quite possible that the principal of the Vocational School overlooked the technical detail in not obtaining authorization for this boy to attend from the Indian Agent. I think, on further consideration, that you will see the matter in this light and I would request payment of the bill.

Yours very truly,

H.A. Tanser,
Inspector-Administrator and Superintendent of Schools.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th ultimo, with reference to the amount requested for the tuition of Pinnance Parker.

As intimated in my letter of the 28th ultimo, this Department cannot be expected to pay tuition grants for Indian children, no matter how deserving they are, unless authority was given for such expenditure previous to the child's entering a school. Otherwise we would have no control over our expenditures.

It can also be inferred from your letter that you do not accept white children from the County of Lambton without the approval of that county. It only seems reasonable that similar approval should be obtained from this Branch in regard to any Indian pupil for whom it is expected that we should provide fees. However, it has been decided to pay the amount of $52.68, but in future no payment for the tuition of Indian children at your school will be made unless our approval has been granted before the child enters the school.

Yours truly,

H.A. Tanner, Esq., M.A., D.Paed.,

Re: Transportation of Pupils to High School.

I have been advised by the Principal of the Wallaceburg High School that there will be no tuition fee for Indian pupils attending that school. Furthermore the pupils from Walpole Island will be able to use the High School Bus from the highway at the lower ferry. The only problem will be transporting these children from the Front to the ferry, approximately 4-5 miles. It may be possible to obtain local cars owned by Indians to do this.

It is understood that some assistance from the Department may be forthcoming in this respect. May we be advised please how this may be handled. It would appear advisable to have more than one car available for this work. The pupil from No. 2 School intends to bicycle to the ferry each day. However a car should be arranged to take this pupil during the winter months. It is expected that there will be four Indian pupils from No. 1 School and 1 pupil from No. 2 School. In addition there are 2 white pupils residents of Walpole who will be attending high school.

It is suggested that each driver submit an account each month on a mileage basis at a stipulated mileage cost. I believe car hire hireage is ten cents, and the approximate daily mileage for one car would be 25 miles.

The alternative would be for them to submit tenders for a contract to do this.

Please advise how much the Department is prepared to pay in this respect.

Robert J. Stallwood, Supt.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: School Transportation.

Enclosed herewith is voucher for payment of transportation expenses of High School pupils to the ferry at the rate of 50¢ per day and Public School pupils from ferry to school (No. 1) at 20 cents per day. One reason for the difference in these rates is the distance travelled in picking up the children for High School. Since this makes a full load for Mr. Williams, I have been taking two High School pupils in my car. Starting this term I have been taking my son in to the Wallaceburg Public School.

A price was quoted by the Wallaceburg Bus Company, which serves Walpole Island two days a week, to make a trip at school hours. They would require a guarantee of $9.00 a trip.

As recommended in a recent letter to the Department, I believe a large Station Wagon that could be used for a school bus and also an ambulance is needed on the Island.

Robert J. Stallwood,

Re: Transportation High School Pupils.

At the present time it is expected that there will be fourteen Indian pupils attend the Wallaceburg High School commencing September 6th, 1949. Seven of those students attended last year and were successful in all their subjects. The remainder are pupils who passed their Entrance examinations last June.

I have arranged to have two cars take ten of these pupils to the High School Bus on the Mainland and one of the cars to bring distant Public School pupils on the return trip to our No. 1 School. This can be arranged on a mileage basis at ten cents per mile, which will cost a total of $4.50 per day. I propose to have the remainder of the pupils taken in my car to Wallaceburg. My wife will drive unless I have business which will require me to go. I may say that since we wish to have our son continue at the Wallaceburg Public School, this trip will be made twice daily anyway. The High School bus was badly overcrowded last year.

May I be advised please if you wish me to submit a separate account for transportation of High School pupils in my car or may it be included in my monthly mileage account?

Please advise if the above arrangements are satisfactory.

Robert J. Stallwood,
Superintendent of Indian Agency.

September 19, 1949.

Re: Transportation - High School Pupils, continued.

I have had talks with the Chairman of the High School Board and with the Manager of the Kent Coach Company which carries High School pupils, with the aim of having one of the High School bus routes cover Walpole Island. The Board does not appear disposed to consider this. He states that the Board receive a Provincial Grant of at least 50 cents per pupil per day for transportation. The balance of the cost of transportation is levied in the form of taxes to ratepayers and by tuition fees on a per capita basis to non-ratepayers.

The Kent Coach Company which operates a bus two days a week on Walpole Island would require a guarantee of $20.00 per day to operate a daily bus at school hours.

It is suggested that when Mr. Morris visits Walpole Island again that we interview the High School Board to include the Island on the regular bus route. It seems to me that we should be entitled to this. I may say that the Board is trying to keep to 5 routes, although some are over 40 miles long and are crowded. To include Walpole, a new route and bus would have to be established.

Robert J. Stallwood,
Superintendent, Walpole Agency.

Memorandum to File:

The Nipissing Indians are not now attending the Garden Village Day School. Thirty-six (36) are going to public and separate schools in Sturgeon Falls and 14 are attending classes in North Bay. As these Indians live along the lake shore paralleled by the North Bay-Sturgeon Falls highway. It is easy to transport them by bus to either of these two cities. Therefore I would not recommend the re-opening of the Garden Village Day School. Although it is a fairly good building, I feel that it will be to the educational advantage of these Indians to have them continue in attendance at white schools. There is also a possibility that some of these children will be able to go much further in the provincial schools than in our own.

There are only five of these children at the Spanish Residential School. There are some of these children in Sturgeon Falls, boarding schools. (Their parents are paying for this).

Bernard F. Neary,

Sturgeon Falls, Sept. 3, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Transportation Nipissing School children, Attending school at Sturgeon Falls

I wish to advise you that I have made temporary arrangements with Frank Beaucage, an Indian of the Nipissing Band, residing at Sturgeon Falls, for the transportation of the Nipissing school children for the coming school term.

Mr. Beaucage has been employed by Paul Galipeau, Union Taxi, for the last four years, and has been transporting the children. He has bought a twelve passenger bus, and carries the regulation insurance, $50,000.00 with Lloyd's Automobile Insurance, effected through the Provincial Service Agency, Limited, 24 King St. W., Toronto. His licence has been approved by the Department of Highways, and the council of the Town of Sturgeon Falls.

Mr. Beaucage will undertake the transportation of approximately 34 Nipissing Band children, attending school at Sturgeon Falls, at a fixed rate of $140.00 per month, $1,400.00 per annum.

If this arrangement is satisfactory to the Department, will you please advise.

JAM/JNM

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

RE: Transportation Nipissing School children, attending school at Sturgeon Falls.

In reply to your letter of September 13, the resolution has not been cancelled, and arrangements with the parents remain the same. They have been paying transportation at the rate of $2.00 a month for each child, which is approximately half of the transportation, and more children are attending school this year.

Although this amount is not always paid monthly, an adjustment is made for any transportation due, when making the interest and royalty distributions.

In the past, we have paid at so many trips a day. Presently the transportation is being done by bus, with a fixed rate of $140.00 per month.

If this change is acceptable, I would like the approval of the Department.

We have received a copy of Reverend Father Oliver's letter of October 28th with reference to Adam Commanda.

While this boy is a member of a band coming under the jurisdiction of Superintendent Marleau, Sturgeon Falls, Ontario, we are writing to you because the boy apparently has been placed as an apprentice at Boston's Garage in your city.

We would appreciate it very much if you would interview the manager of the garage and also the boy himself and let us know the length of time that he will have to serve as an apprentice and the expenditure that will be required to assist him during his apprenticeship. Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6486, file 42043-3, part 3)
Dear Mr Neary...

Adam Commanda, son of Peter Commanda of Bear Island in Mr. J.A. Marlowe's agency left us some time ago to work with a garage man in town here... about three weeks ago. The arrangement was very unsatisfactory since there was very little work to do at the garage, the tourist season being over and Adam ended up by being odd job man. He asked us what we thought he should do and an opportunity presented itself of getting him to Sault Ste Marie Ontario. He went up with Father Bernard Mayhew and was fortunate enough to get accepted as an apprentice at Boston's Garage. I understand they have a fine training school there. Father Mayhew writes that Adam is interested in the work but that he cannot possibly carry on financially with the apprentice's wages.

It seems a shame to have him quit when it might be possible for him to get help from the Department. I am sure that Mr Laurence would be glad to advise in this matter, and am taking the risk of having Fr Mayhew go to him since Mr Laurence is at the Sault and has done something of the same type before.

Yours very sincerely,

(Rev) J.R. Oliver S.J.
Principal....

Mr B.F. Neary
Supt Education
Indian Affairs Branch.

Re: Transportation
Nipissing Band School children.

As previously reported, the transportation of school children of the Nipissing Band, to schools in Sturgeon Falls has been through an agreement with Frank Beaucage, since the commencement of the school term in September.

At the time the agreement was made, Mr. Beaucage had a school bus which was repossessed shortly after the commencement of the September term because of his failure to make the necessary payments. Beaucage claims that delay by the branch in forwarding his monthly cheque was responsible for this failure.

Since that time, Mr. Beaucage has been able to honour his agreement by hiring taxis from different concerns in Sturgeon Falls to carry the children. This arrangement has worked after a fashion, but is in imminent danger of breaking down, due to the fact that different companies in turn have refused the work, because of Beaucage's failure to pay regularly.

Mr. Beaucage's present agreement is with the Benoit Taxi. Because of Beaucage's reputation for incurring debts, Benoit is concerned about a small bill of some $12.00 owed to him by Beaucage to date.

May I recommend that the agreement with Mr. Beaucage be terminated and that a new agreement be made with the Benoit Taxi to transport these children to Sturgeon Falls at the same rate ($140.00 per month) as was paid Mr. Beaucage.

cont'd...2
Mr. Benoit has indicated his willingness to enter into such an agreement.

In conclusion I should like to record the fact that Mr. Beaucage is industrious and conscientious, but that he seems incapable of carrying on an independent business, particularly as far as responsibilities in money matters are concerned.

J. H. Gordon,
In Charge of Indian Agency,
Sturgeon Falls

Extract from Mr. J.H. Gordon's Report dated March 7th.

Superintendent Marleau has encouraged this trend in recent years to good effect, particularly as far as education is concerned. The Indian day school at the village is closed and all the children attend schools either in North Bay or Sturgeon Falls, depending on their location on the Reserve. The local teachers speak well of their Indian pupils and tell me that in deportment and attainment, with the possible exception of literature, that they are indistinguishable from the White pupils.

Unfortunately the road into the village is such that the dozen or so children living there during the winter months are unable to attend school. This situation should be remedied as soon as possible. The ideal solution would be for the families living in the village to move to locations on the highway for the winter months. Alternately the road to the village could be snow fenced and more efficiently ploughed. The danger in the latter course would be the encouragement it might give to those living on the Highway at present to move back into the village. I do not believe that the small school in the village should be re-opened under any circumstances judging from the remarkably well trained Indian children from the Reserve who are attending the White schools.

Dear Mr. Marleau,

With reference to my contract for the transporting of school children from the Garden Village Reserve and Mosquito Creek to Sturgeon Falls, I would very much appreciate your considering increasing the amount allowed for this service.

As you are aware, I transport 36 children twice daily each school day to and from the Garden Village Reserve, I use two cars for this purpose. The return distance is 12 miles, so that in order to service the reserve, my cars travel a total of 48 miles per day. In addition, I send a car to Mosquito Creek twice daily. The return distance is 14 miles, so that my car travels 28 miles each day on this trip. This makes a total of 76 miles per day which my cars travel. I understand that this coming year there will be more children to transport, and it will probably require a third car.

At present I receive $140.00 per month, or roughly $7.00 per day. I was wondering if you could arrange to increase this to $9.00 per day, or $3.00 per car, which would work out to $130.00 per month. My cars will be travelling about 100 miles per day with the third car, and it appears to me that this would be reasonable. Your co-operation would be very much appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Rheo Benoit.

Dear Sir:

I have a letter from the Secretary-Treasurer of the Peterbell School Board requesting payment of tuition fees for Treaty Indian children who, he states, are in attendance. It is practically the same letter as you forwarded to us under cover of your letter of October 9, 1941.

In my reply of October 20 I advised you that Mr. Arnell would visit your Agency. However, other important matters have arisen which require Mr. Arnell's services and it will probably be several months before he will have an opportunity of going to your Agency.

The School Board requests tuition fees for two children of Simon Fans and one child of Jim Kooses. Are these men recognized as Indians and how long have they resided at Peterbell? As you are aware, if these families have resided off the reserve for a period of 18 months the Department cannot accept responsibility either for their welfare or the education of their children. As pointed out in my letter of October 20, I am under the impression that if we continue allowing payments for the education of children at places along the railway lines the majority of the Indians will soon be residing in or close to many of these small towns.

I will not reply to the letter of the Secretary-Treasurer of the Peterbell School Board until your reply is received.

Yours truly,

Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey.

While in Ottawa I intended to more thoroughly go into the matter of Indians attending the Public school at Moosonee, but neglected to do so.

On October 25th, I wrote to you that there are 15 Indians attending the school and 17 white children, and suggested that possibly it could be arranged with the Ontario Dept. of Health that they and our Dept. supply milk and health biscuits for all the children of this school. The school principal has already arranged with a chapter of the I.O.B.E. to supply all the children with Vitamin capsules and I believe they have been taking these daily for some time.

This particular Public school has had an exceptional type of man for teacher during the past year and a half—peculiarly suited for the mixed community. I call him peculiarly suited in that his humanity, kindness and interest does not draw a color line. His attitude is that he is teaching and directing young intelligence, according to its capacity and that he is trying to shape future Canadian citizens to some useful purpose. He maintains as I do, that intelligence is not limited by skin pigmentation, and is proud of being able to offer Indian children the same opportunity that he gives to children such as mine. The fact that Indian and white children in a community such as this can attend school on an equal footing and mix daily in work and play without even the least tinge of bias on the part of either Teacher or children, is in my opinion a remarkable example of what can be done in future educational outlook for our James Bay Indians. In a way this school serves to point out to us the possibilities of day schools for Indians in Northern localities, which is one of the discussed probable means of bringing education to them.

We should do everything possible to encourage Indian Attendance at Moosonee Public School, and I think it would be of definite value to introduce the daily use of milk and biscuits for this purpose, aside altogether from the health viewpoint. Will you undertake to contact the Provincial Authorities regarding their share in the proposition.

Dear Doctor Orford:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 7th and have noted with interest that Mr. Allan Reesor, employed for a time as teacher at the Anglican Residential School, is anxious to have one of the pupils, James Sutherland, Jr., proceed with his studies at Toronto.

You will be interested to learn that a somewhat similar request was received by this Branch from Mr. Reesor about a year ago. He was then in charge of a classroom at the Alberni Residential School, British Columbia, and was deeply impressed with the intelligence of at least one member of his class. Mr. Reesor's request was very sympathetically reviewed at that time and finally rejected. As a matter of fact, during the last year we have had to make provision for two or three Indian pupils that had been taken by teachers and ex-teachers to their homes in Canadian cities. Indian pupils removed from their environment and from contact with their relatives invariably become dissatisfied.

You have probably learned by this time that Mr. Reesor is a very unusual individual, hopelessly idealistic and hopelessly impracticable. It would be interesting to know whether or not he ever discussed this proposal with his parents. Certainly there are thousands of bright boys in Toronto without homes that would be glad of an opportunity to reside with Mr. Reesor.

I have written to the Deputy Minister of Education in Toronto regarding the supplying of powdered milk for Moosonee School children. When his reply is received I will advise you.

The Moosonee P.S. in the month of September had 19 Indian children on the register. The aggregate attendance for the 19 School days was 192 with only 5 of the above pupils starting on time. Each of these 5 pupils attended 17 days and were absent 2 days. Eight pupils who started late in the month had perfect attendance records from the time of their beginning.

The other 6 pupils were all late beginners and had the following attendance records—present 11 absent 3; present 7 absent 2 (3); present 5 absent 1; present 10 absent 2.

Of these 19 pupils four went away at the end of September with their parents and are still on the trap lines; three others attended a few days in October then left for the bush with their parents; one was removed from School to Hospital after seven days; and the other ten who were regular attendants had an aggregate of 196 days in a 21 day School month with an aggregate absence of only 14 days.

In November there were 22 School days and there were 10 Indian pupils on the register. Six of these had perfect attendance records for 22 days. One child released from Hospital 3 days late had perfect attendance of 19 days. One child was present 20, absent 2; one present 16, absent 6; and the tenth was classed as 3 days present 19 absent but was under my care in Hospital for all of those 19 days.

The average of attendance is of course brought down by those on the register who go to School only when their parents are at Moosonee and who spend most of the School year in the bush. Those pupils who live at Moosonee all year have an attendance record over 90% which is equal to that of the white children.

Under some circumstances I would have been happy to have seen this lad take advantage of a good opportunity, but I do not consider that it would be to his advantage to have gone to Mr. Reesor. I think Dr. Orford should have realized that too.

Would it be possible for you to drop me a line sometime advising me what is the Government's policy for the Indians. Is it that they should continue indefinitely as Wards of the Government or is it that eventually they should become citizens of the country. To which of these ends should we in the Residential Schools be preparing the Indian children who come to us?

Thanking you again for your kindness in advising me re the above pupil and looking forward to hearing from you again. I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Thompson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 6th instant and have noted with interest the information contained therein. It is gratifying to note that the action taken by the Branch with respect to Mr. Reesor's request was satisfactory to you.

With respect to the question contained in the penultimate paragraph of your communication, I can state without hesitation that the policy of the Government for half a century or more has been to so arrange its educational and general welfare program in a manner that will encourage the Indian population to accept increasingly the duties and responsibilities of democratic citizenship, and there are few that would dispute that this must, in the very nature of things, be the Indian's goal.

I am sending forward two or three Branch reports which, I trust, will be of interest to you, and the study of which will give you a fairly clear insight into what the Government is attempting to do. In this connection, I may state that a Seminar Conference was held a few years ago at the University of Toronto. A very full discussion took place between officials from the United States Department of Indian Affairs, Washington, and the officials of this Department with respect to Indian policy and objectives in Indian policy. A report of this Conference was later published by the University of Toronto Press and I feel sure you would find the report interesting and very helpful. It is altogether likely that a copy could be secured for you either by Canon Dixon or Dr. Alderwood.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Rossor:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 23rd, in which you ask for a copy of the letter sent by this Branch to the Indian Agent at Moose Factory, Dr. Orford, in which we dealt with your request to provide instruction for an Indian boy in Toronto.

I regret to state that I am unable, under existing regulations, to accede to this request. Official letters or letters dealing with Departmental business cannot be released by Departmental officials. In the case of official letters relating to public issues, these can be tabled at any time on motion of a Member of the House of Commons, and when so tabled become accessible to the Press. In the case of inter-departmental correspondence, however, or letters that go to Indian Agents, or Principals in charge of Residential Schools, these have invariably been looked upon as private or confidential communications. Motions from time to time to have them tabled have always been rejected by the House.

I can assure you, however, that in my letter to Dr. Orford dated December 12th, 1945, there was no reference whatever to your past work among the Indians, nor was there any reference to information received by me or by any other official of the Department from a United Church minister. Your request was refused on the grounds that during the past two or three years we were called upon to make provision for two or three Indian pupils who had been taken by teachers and ex-teachers to their homes in Canadian cities. In our letter we stated:

"Those teachers, prompted no doubt by sympathy and interest in the pupil, took on an obligation

.....that they
that they simply could not fulfill. Indian pupils removed from their environment and from contact with their relatives invariably become dissatisfied."

We expressed the view also that James Sutherland should continue to attend the Residential School at Moose Factory until he had completed Grade 8; at which time his claims for a tuition grant would be carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the Department. In this connection, you will be interested to learn that the Appropriation from which tuition grants are paid, which is passed annually by Parliament, has never been exhausted at any time during the eight years that I have occupied a position in this Branch. It has never seemed to me reasonable, therefore, that private citizens should be called upon to make provision for Indian pupils anxious to proceed with high school courses. I have never at any time doubted for a moment your interest for Indian pupils and in their welfare. There was nothing personal in the decision reached with respect to this particular boy. It was based on our experience with other somewhat similar cases and was made in the belief that it was in your own interest and in the interest of the boy himself.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Acting Director.

Mr. Phil Phelan

Dear Mr. Phelan:

From time to time we receive requests particularly from the General Hospital in Toronto that we take care of the education of certain pupils by sending a teacher to the hospital. We usually comply.

Recently we have been requested to endeavour to teach reading to a 17 year old Indian (Harry Whiskeyham) from Rupert's House, James Bay.

We have been informed that if we undertake this that your Department would be prepared to reimburse us for the cost involved. Would you kindly advise us if this information is correct?

Very truly yours,

The Toronto General Hospital has asked the Toronto & Sub. Div. Sch. Bd. to send a visiting teacher to a patient Harry Whiskeyjohn, 17 yr. old Indian from Rupert House. Dear Phil:

Answering your letter of May 29th.

I would say that teaching this boy should be worth $1.50 for each visit. Our visiting teacher can teach him on three different afternoons each week until the end of June. That would mean twelve visits in all, a total of $18.00.

Will this be satisfactory to you?

I will have her start this Monday.

Yours very truly,

J. M. Bennett
Ottawa, June 5, 1946.

Dear Mr. Dillon:

I have your letter of the 9th ultimo, with reference to Harry Whiskeychan, who is in Toronto General Hospital.

At that time you should forward an account, showing the number of visits at the rate stated above, and cheque will be issued in favour of the Toronto and Suburban Separate School Board.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, May 31st, 1947.

Dear Sirs:

With reference to your letter of May 29th, payments made to School Section No. 1 in the Township of Moose were as follows:

1. April 15, 1944 - $150.44 for the calendar year 1943.
2. March 31, 1945 - $453.68 " " " 1944.
3. Feb. 17, 1947 - $384.84 " " " 1945.

We have always paid for the tuition of Indian children at this school when we receive the usual account from the public school inspector. Apparently there was a change in inspector in that district and when we heard of this we wrote to Mr. G.L. Woodruff, School Inspector, Cochrane, Ontario on December 17, 1946, advising him that we had not received an account for the year 1945. He forwarded this to us on January 27th.

We are quite prepared to pay for the tuition of the children during the year 1946 as soon as we receive the account from the inspector.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary

Moose Factory, Ontario,
April 23rd, 1948.

Mr. F.D. Wallace, Principal of the Public School, Moosonee has taken quite an interest in the Indian children, about 35 in all, attending his school.

He reports that the school board at Moosonee supplies milk for all children twice daily, giving each child about 10 oz. This, we understand, has increased the percentage of attendance from the lower sixties to the upper eighties, to say nothing of the improvement in the general health. In addition to the milk, Halibut Liver Oil has been given regularly, the children being lined up and given their dose individually with the result that colds have been practically nil.

Mr. Wallace requests a supply of Vitamin biscuits for next year also "Westchem Oil" for which I am enclosing requisition.

Attention Mr. G. Armstrong.
Re. Lawrence Cheechoo.

The above mentioned Indian Youth of Eastmain, Moose Factory, Ont., age 22 years, has been discharged from Weston Sanitorium after having spent about 3 years there. During this time he had worked hard and has made every effort to improve his education, having been under the tuition of resident teacher in the Hospital. He is most anxious to improve his education and has asked if there is anything that the Department can do to advance his education. In order that I may be conversant with his present standing, I sent him over to Moosonee to interview the Principal of the Public School and received the following report:

Standing Grade VIII
Aptitude Good
Reasoning Good
I.Q. A-plus for Grade VIII.

As Lawrence is most anxious to further his education, I would suggest a business course, since at his advanced years the General Course would be too costly and he would be too old before it would be completed. With a business course he may make a good Grade 1 or perhaps a grade II Clerk.

Any advice or suggestion that you have have in assisting such cases as this will be appreciated.

J. Allan
Superintendent
James Bay Indian Agency

Re: Allen Kitchen, Rupert House Band No. 68

I have your letter of the 23rd inst., in connection with the above referenced Indian boy.

I received a letter, on August 3rd., from The Beck Memorial Sanatorium, London, Ont., reporting that this boy was ready for discharge and suggested that he be placed with his Aunt Mrs. Wm. J. Morrison, Doherty, Ont., near North Bay, Ont. I arranged transportation for this boy and requested Mrs. Morrison to advise me when he reached Doherty and was in her care. To date, I have heard nothing from Mrs. Morrison and your letter intimating that he has been discharged to the home of his Aunt in Doherty is the first notification received in this office.

The Superintendent of the Beck Memorial Sanatorium advises that this boy completed his public school work and has been recommended for his Entrance. I believe that this boy has made a request that he continue with his studies at the home of his Aunt and is very anxious to continue with his education.

He was admitted to the Sanatorium in July 1944, and he may have been hospitalised at Moosonee or Moose Factory for sometime prior to that date, and we cannot find any record in this office as to whether or not he attended school and what grade he had reached prior to his admission.
It would be appreciated if you would advise if this boy is enrolled in High School and furnish particulars as to school and location in order that I may follow his progress.

J.S.Allan
Superintendent
James Bay Indian Agency

The cost of electricity for the Principal's residence is $67.19 more than at the Agent's residence. I discussed the increased cost with both Indian Agent McKinnon and the Principal, Father Ross, and discovered that Father Ross had installed an electric heater in his water tank without permission or authority from Ottawa. This undoubtedly is the reason why the electricity costs are so much higher in his residence. Mr. McKinnon has had several discussions with Father Ross regarding the excess cost of electricity for his residence. Father Ross now wants to heat his hot water tank from his kitchen oil-burning range. This will mean the moving of the hot water tank from its present location in the cellar up to a place in the kitchen near the range. I informed Father Ross that he must not make any further changes or alterations in his residence without authority from Ottawa.

When this house was built provision was made to heat the water for domestic use by a coal-burning jacket heater in the cellar. Father Ross's only excuse for installing this unit was it required a lot of attention. I would suggest that orders be sent to Indian Agent McKinnon advising him to instruct Father Ross not to make any other changes or alterations in his building without first submitting the same through the Indian Agent's office to headquarters for approval. I would further recommend that deductions be made from the Principal's salary to pay for the excess cost of electricity used in his house since he installed the electric heater. No doubt Mr. McKinnon, if requested, can obtain the actual cost of the operating of the electric hot water heater.

J. E. Morris,

Shubenacadie, N.S. December 30, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Res., Ottawa.

When I was making arrangements to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mrs. Elsie Basque who taught school on this reservation, I was asked by the applicant, our present teacher, to furnish her with information re the number of pupils and the highest grade to be taught. I took the matter up with Mrs. Basque and was informed that the highest grade attending school was grade five. On the strength of this she accepted the position and reported for duty. A few weeks later a young girl of this reservation, Annie Marr, aged 16, who had been working in Halifax, returned home and began attending school. She is in Grade 8 and insists on attending school. The teacher claims she is unable to handle this grade due to the change in teaching methods and the new subjects on the present day curriculum. The parents of the child claim that provision should be made for the continuation of her studies. The teacher offered to resign but no successor can be found.

While in Halifax this girl worked at St. Mary's Convent and while there arranged with the Sister Superior to allow her to attend the school in the afternoon. Thus she would work in the morning, go to school in the afternoon and work and study in the evenings. The girl and her parents claim she is determined to become a teacher. I asked the Superior for her opinion of her and was told she had both ability and determination. I interviewed Mrs. Basque her former teacher, and was told in confidence that Annie Marr, while attending the day school on the reserve, was just an ordinary student, having no great amount of ability or

P.T.O.
ambition. I have talked to the girl who seems determined to be a teacher, and to continue her studies. I pointed out to her that if her case, beginning grade 8 at the age of 16 would have her in high school at the age of twenty or more which is three or four years older than the average. At the end of our interview she still appeared to be determined to become a teacher.

The parents claim that provisions should be made by the Department for her continuation in school. They are unable to do so as they have a large family and could not meet the expense of boarding her anywhere to attend another school. Shubenacadie village school is five miles distant and out of the question. The residential school is filled to capacity and would not solve the problem as any students of promise from that institution attend the village school after completing Grade 8.

St. Mary's convent in Halifax (Sisters of Charity) would board her and allow her to attend the convent school for $4.00 per week. This is what the parents desire and would like the Department to pay for. The school in question is a public school and the curriculum is identical with all public schools of the province. I might add that this girl's sister reached grade ten and was a good student. Her mother, an Indian by birth, was a teacher in Prince Edward Island prior to her marriage.

I am anxious that every Indian boy or girl showing promise should be encouraged to further their studies. They are and will be needed here in the future. Our former teacher Mrs. Basque is a very fine type of woman and quite capable as a teacher. It is unfortunate that this girl could not continue on here until grade ten or so but that appears impossible. In this case I would recommend that this family be assisted until the end of this teaching year, June 1944, by the Department meeting the boarding charges of $4.00 per week. At the end of that time I will interview her teachers in Halifax and ascertain if this pupil shows ability and ambition enough to justify the continuation of the suggested arrangement.

Please advise.

H. C. Rice,
Indian Agent

Ottawa, January 4, 1944.

Mr. H. C. Rice, Indian Agent, Shubenacadie, N.S.

Re: Annie Marr.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of December 30, written by you on behalf of the marginally-noted Indian girl.

The parents of this girl should be told that the Department is under no statutory obligation to provide instruction for Indian pupils who have reached the age of 16 years. Despite this fact, an attempt is made by this Branch from year to year to help a limited number of pupils who have been exceptionally successful in their elementary courses and who have won creditable marks in their Entrance examinations. This girl is, as you say, somewhat old to begin a course of high school study at this time and her fitness to become a teacher at any time should be discussed with a competent educationist, preferably the public school inspector for the district. In view of her anxiousness to succeed, however, the Department is prepared to pay for her tuition at the St. Mary's Convent at Halifax until the end of the present academic year. At that time her case should be very carefully and sympathetically reviewed and a specific recommendation with respect to her sent forward to the Department at that time.

It is a matter of extreme regret that the teacher now in charge of the day school on the reserve is incapable of providing instruction above Grade 5. It seems scarcely worth while to keep a teacher employed who is so lacking in the necessary qualifications. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you could at the earliest date recommend a qualified teacher for that position.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Extract from Indian Agent Rice's report on the Shubenacadie Indian Agency for the period October, 1943, to January, 1944, inclusive.

This year from the Truro Indian Day School there were two pupils sent into the town school doing their last year of Junior High. Their ability warranted more attention than the day school teacher could afford to give them and I arranged for their entrance. One has since been withdrawn and sent to St. Martha's T.B. Unit with moderately active T.B.; the other, because of family conditions, will not likely continue school much longer. Dear Mr. Rice,

As the teacher of the Indian Day School here, I would like to suggest that two of my pupils will be completing Grade Eight this coming June. As both these girls namely, Violet Mae Paul and Ruby Marie Howe have been very apt, studious and ambitious during their seven years at the Day School, I would like to request that other provisions be made by the Department of Indian Affairs to enable them to complete their education.

One, Violet Mae Paul began school at the age of nine, (no school was provided in Shubenacadie until 1939), and has proved herself a very studious and ambitious young lady leading her classes throughout. Violet is now interested in stenography.

The other Ruby Marie Howe began school at the same time. She too has been ambitious and industrious during her attendance at the Day School. She is now interested in nursing.

As their teacher I am greatly interested in their welfare and would like to have both of them given a chance to have their ambitions realized, but help from the Department is necessary.

As an Indian graduate of Sacred Heart Academy, Meteghan N.S., may I suggest that both these young ladies be sent there this coming school term of 1947-48, and be allowed to continue attending same until their education is completed?

Sacred Heart Academy is under the direction of the Sisters of Charity and I feel certain that these two pupils of mine would be welcome students there.

I am enclosing a record of their examination marks at the half-year with the hope that you will approve of same and deem it worthy to recommend these two girls to the Department for aid in furthering their education.

Trusting to receive a favourable reply at the earliest possible date,

I am,

Sincerely yours,

PROSPECTUS

Sacred Heart Academy
Meteghan, N. S.
On Saint Mary's Bay

THE SACRED HEART ACADEMY on St. Mary's Bay is under the direction of the Sisters of Charity of Halifax, Nova Scotia. It affords to its pupils many advantages as regards healthfulness of situation.

The rules governing the Academy are simple and practical.

The Junior Classes embrace the necessary studies preparatory to High School Work.

The Senior Course embraces the studies of Four Years of High School. The Young Ladies who so desire may write the provincial examination in the Academy, since this is a legal examination station.

Beside French and English which are taught in all the divisions, pupils may take a course in Latin.

TERMS

Board and Tuition for School Year $250.00
Music extra $30.00
Day Pupils $25.00
GENERAL REGULATIONS

1. The Academy is not responsible for money, jewelry, etc., unless deposited in the office.

2. Pupils are forbidden to use matches, candles, no other but electric lights to be used.

Pupils are not to appropriate or make use of anything belonging to another pupil. Caps, coats, etc., not to be loaned without permission of Sister in charge.

Before admitting new pupils references from reliable source are requested. The record of the present scholarship of each pupil entering must also be shown.

Visits home will be permitted at Thanksgiving Christmas vacation—two weeks, from Holy Thursday until 7 p.m. Easter Monday. Parents are earnestly requested not to ask to have their children go home at other times nor to take them out for automobile drives. Pupils who do not go home on free days will not be allowed to visit the homes of their friends.

Books, Stationery and Medicines form extra charges. Pupils are requested to provide, if possible, their own supply of stationery, stamps, etc., also to bring their sewing, crocheting, knitting materials, etc.

The Scholastic Year is divided into four terms or sessions, each payable in advance.

The opening dates of each session are as follows:

September 8th. February 1st.
November 15th. April 15th.

Unless a pupil's financial accounts have been satisfactorily settled before the opening of a new scholastic year she will not be received the year following.

We request the parents not to interfere with the regular work of the school, by withdrawing their children even for a few hours while the Academy is in session. Such interruptions usually lower the pupils in their classes, lessen their interest in school work and render them unhappy, because boarding-school rules appear to them too strict. We expect the parents to co-operate with us in observing the Academy rules which have been formed for the betterment of their children.
Sacred Heart Academy,
Wolfeboro, N.H.

It will be most gratifying to you as it was to us here to learn of the fine record of these Indian girls. It might be pointed out that they are the only Indian girls in these Institutions and it speaks very highly of their former teacher, Mrs. Elsie Basque, of this Reserve. She deserves much credit for the fine way she prepared these girls for their later studies, for without the proper background they could never attempt to attain the record they have.

It is learned from correspondence with the respective Superior's in charge of these Institutions, that these girls are upright and ladylike as well as being intelligent and studious. We here are very proud of these girls, and I am sure this pride...
will be shared with those at Departmental Headquarters whose interest and foresight made it possible for these girls to further their studies. It appears now that these girls have the honour not to break the trust that was placed in them and it is recommended that when the time comes for these girls to further their education, the same interest and co-operation will be extended.

Application is hereby made for tuition grants in the amount of $250.00 each, for the captionally noted Indian girls who have been attending the Convents as above indicated during the past academic year.

Marie Howe and Viola Paul were in Grade IX during the past year and graduated with high standing in the school; Miss Paul leading her class and Miss Howe coming second. Copies of their marks are attached hereto for your information.

Isabel Knockwood was taking her Junior Matriculation at Saint Joseph's Convent, Maboo, N. S. Her marks during the year were highly satisfactory and at the 1st and 2nd quarter examinations, led her class. In view of the fact that she was taking Junior Matriculation, it was necessary for her to write Provincial examinations and the result will not be known before around August 17th or 18th. However, it is felt by her teachers that she will pass these examinations with a high rating. As Miss Knockwood is only 17 years of age and is desirous to enter the nursing profession (minimum age 18) she has requested that she be given the opportunity to return to the Convent to take her Senior Matriculation. Otherwise, she would have to remain idle for one year awaiting the minimum age at which she could be admitted as a trainee in any of the local hospitals.

Indian Affairs (rg 10 Volume 6486, file 42051-3, part 1)
Miss Paul intends to complete her Junior Matriculation and take a business course. Miss Howe intends to continue her studies with a view to entering the nursing profession.

In view of the fine record established by all these girls, it is strongly recommended that this application for tuition grants of $250 each be given favourable consideration.

It is also strongly recommended that the $75.00 for clothing allowance which was allowed these girls last year, be again granted in order that they may be properly clothed for the academic year.

Re: Miss Theresa Bradford,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

The captionally noted Indian girl who resides on the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve, has been attending the High School in the village of Shubenacadie some five miles distance for the last two years. She is at present in Grade eleven and we have been advised by her teacher that if her attendance were more punctual she would experience no difficulty in obtaining her junior matriculation this year.

This girl walks a distance of ten miles every day in order to attend school and it is felt that if it were possible to have her board at the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S. which is only a distance of one mile from the high school, she would devote more time to her studies and would also enable her to be more punctual in her attendance. I might say that this girl has a lot of ambition and intends to enter a Nursing School next year and it is strongly recommended that the Department assist her in every way to help her obtain her junior matriculation which is necessary before entering an accredited school for Nurses.
Mrs. Mary Bradford, mother of this girl, is a widow who receives a pension in the amount of $25.75 a month from her son who is a TB patient at the D.V.A. hospital, Cornwallis, N.S. It is very seldom that Mrs. Bradford requests any assistance from the Indian Affairs Branch and manages her small pension in such a way that she manages to get by, as far as groceries and clothing for herself is concerned. However, in view of the fact that her daughter Theresa is attending school, it is necessary that the girl be presentable at all times. She has requested that a winter coat, two dresses and a sweater be purchased for her daughter the cost to be borne by the Indian Affairs Branch. This amount would entail an expenditure of approximately $50.00, and it is strongly recommended that the necessary authority be granted for local purchase of the articles mentioned herein.

I personally feel, in view of the circumstances and the ambition shown by this girl that we should do everything in our power to assist her in realizing her ambition to become a nurse.

I trust this request will meet favourable consideration.

H.G. RICE, Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency.

She also mentions that the amount we allow her for janitor services is too small. Would you recommend an increase and, if so, let me know how much.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA, Ont.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of March 19, 1946, having reference to the wood supply at Red Bank Indian Day School.

For your information I might say that I have had considerable difficulty with wood both at Red Bank and El Ground during the present year. At Red Bank it so happens there are no saw mills operating during the summer months and consequently we were unable to procure wood until the mills above Red Bank started cutting in the fall with the result that the wood supply was not as dry as it should have been. The high prices prevailing for lumber products has caused those who formerly cut hardwood to abandon this type of wood for the time being.

I hope to visit Red Bank shortly and shall try and have Mrs. Watt provided with enough kindling wood to finish the present term.

In reference to the second paragraph of your letter I would say that Mrs. Watt is a very good janitor and I would recommend that beginning April 1st., 1946 I would recommend that Mrs. Mary Jane Watt be paid at the rate of $75.00 per year. I would also recommend that Mr. Adelin LeBlanc janitor at Big Cove School and Miss Delphine Murphy janitress at El Ground School be both raised to the same level. This would put all janitors in this Agency on the same basis.

I would also request authority to purchase wood for the four schools in the Agency as shortly after the beginning of the next fiscal year as it is possible to procure same.

Gentlemen:

born April 11, 1916 at
