MicMac Tribe of Indians

Mrs. Lawrence Noel of Clinton, Maine, who before her marriage was Mary Elizabeth Peter Paul of the MicMac Tribe of Indians, approached this Division for assistance in obtaining further education. She has had one year at Thomas Business College in Waterville, Maine, and she wishes to complete her course there. The year's tuition, plus books, would cost approximately $235.00.

She feels that this education would be of great help to her in maintaining her family. Her husband has a spinal injury and is not able to do any heavy work but he does maintain a farm. They have two small children.

We have no fund in this state for the further education of Indians. She suggested that she thought it was possible to obtain such assistance through your Department and we are writing to you to find out if there is any validity to this statement and whether or not it would be possible for you to assist a Mic Mac Indian in this state to obtain such an education.

Sincerely yours,

Muriel T. Covell
Case Work Supervisor
Division of Poor Relief

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6486, file 42055-3, part 4)
October 2, 1941.

Dear Madam:

I have your letter of September 29 with regard to the case of Mrs. Lawrence Noel of Clinton, Maine, who before her marriage was Mary Elizabeth Peter Paul of Redbank, N.B.

You do not state whether the husband of Mrs. Noel is a United States citizen, but I presume that he is. According to the provisions of the Indian Act, Mrs. Noel would cease to be an Indian upon her marriage to a white man and is no longer under the jurisdiction of this department.

In the circumstances it would not be possible for this department to assist Mrs. Noel as suggested.

Yours very truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th., instant File 105-55 referring to Miss Marie Ginish, North West Bridge, N.B., applying for assistance to enable her to obtain higher education. From my experience I find that it is an absolute waste of money, as there are a few Indians belonging to this agency that have taken courses at a university, and they are certainly not any more progressive than the others.

Dear Sir:

The reason for these families living near Bathurst, as far as I can find, and by what the Indians themselves say, is for the purpose of sending the children to school. Those families who are living near Bathurst seem to be of rather better type than the ordinary Mic-Mac.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the Paul and Prisk children. I note that you state that these two families live on the Pabineau Reserve. On reviewing the 1939 census I note that no mention is made of any Indians living on that reserve. I would like to know at what work the heads of these families are employed. Dear Sir:

I have just received your letter of the 19th instant File 103-55 referring to attendance report of two children named Prisk who have attended the Big River School, East Bathurst, N.B. In reply I beg to inform you that these are Indian children of Joseph Prisk who is a member of the Bathurst band, and resides on the Papineau Reserve. There is only a few members of the Bathurst band and of course there is no school at the reserve, and the nearest school to the part of the reserve on which Prisk resides, is the Big River School, at East Bathurst. I do not believe there is any less expensive way to school these children than to let them attend that school.

With regard to this being the first time such reports have been submitted, I believe that it is, but there have been Indian children attending schools near Bathurst for some years back, but apparently they did not think about asking for payment before, and as long as they were satisfied I did not say anything about it. However they became aware that the Department does pay for Indian children who attend white schools, and so applied to me for whatever amount the Department paid for such service. I then sent the proper forms for the report and trust that it was the proper thing to do.

Regarding the work Jos. Prisk does, it is any kind of odd jobs he can pick up, such as work in the lumber woods, sometimes with white farmers, and does a little farming of his own on the reserve. He tried to enlist in the armed forces but could not pass the Medical Examination.

P.S. I spoke about those children in my letter of 16th instant.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 23rd., File 103-55 referring to the Paul and Prisk children who reside on the Papineau Reserve. With regard to these Indians who live on the Papineau Reserve, they have always been known as the Bathurst band: There are four families, namely John Paul, Joseph Prisk, Paul Prisk, and Peter Sewell.

The heads of each of these families are employed as follows.

John Paul - is in the army and oversea.
Joseph Prisk - is on the reserve (Papineau) where he does some farming, and works at odd jobs for white people.

Peter Sewell - Lives on the Papineau Reserve and works for white people, on the farm and in the lumber woods.

There is an Indian girl of the Eel Ground Reserve named Marie Ginnish, who has been persistently asking me to request the Department to have her attend the convent at Newcastle, to take a stenographer's course. The cost to the Dept. would be $28.00 per month. This girl will be able to provide the books required; without your assistance, the cost of which will be $15.00.

This girl attended the Eel Ground Indian Day School, and passed the eighth grade with high marks, and then she completed 9 and 10 grades work through a correspondence course. She is highly recommended by her teachers as a bright student. What do you think should be done in her case? So far, we have not had much luck with the Indians down here whom we have provided with higher education, but now when the demand for clerical workers is urgent, they may have better luck. This girl's mother is a white woman, and Marie herself, does not resemble an Indian.

I would be pleased to have you decide this issue, and let me know your views before January 1st.

Indian Agent.

Before making any decision regarding Marie Ginnish, I would appreciate your advising me of the progress that Dorothy Bernard is making. The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

In answer to your letter of the 24th December, 1942, F. 103-55, concerning an Indian girl named Marie Ginnish, of the Mal Ground Reserve, who has been asking to be sent to the convent to take a business course, I have the honour to advise you that after some considerable correspondence, I have learned from the principal of Success Business College, Moncton, that Dorothy Bernard, who is taking a course with that college is expected to finish about the end of July 1943. The principal states that she is a bit slow in shorthand, but otherwise is progressing fairly well.

The above is the information you asked for, before a decision could be made as to whether or not you would give Marie Ginnish the business course she has been asking about. My letter of December 21st, 1942, dealt with this girl's qualifications and circumstances.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
January 25, 1945.

EXD.

Mr. Chas. Hudson, Indian Agent, Richibucto, N.B.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with further reference to the application of Marie Ginnish for a tuition grant.

It has been decided to allow an amount of $25.00 a month for a period not exceeding 6 months to enable this girl to take a stenography course.

It should be definitely understood by all parties concerned that this is the maximum amount the Department will allow. You should request the Principal of the school which she attends to send you a monthly report in order that you may make certain that she is taking advantage of the opportunity that is being offered to her. In the event of her reports being unsatisfactory, you should ask the Department for further instructions.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Moncton, N. B.
Jan. 27, 1943

Mr. Charles Hudson
Indian Agent
Richibucto, N. B.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter requesting the approximate date when Dorothy Bernard will complete her course.

The average time required for this course is 10 months. She should then be through about the middle of July. It is difficult to say the exact date when she will graduate because graduation here depends upon completion of work, and students failing on any subject are given a review and a second examination.

Miss Bernard is slow in her shorthand and typewriting, and will take the full 10 months, possibly a little longer, to complete her course.

I want to apologise for not answering your inquiry before; I overlooked it. If there is any further information you want I shall be glad to assist you.

Yours truly,

Success Business College Ltd.
per A. MacD. Cooke
Principal

I respectfully submit herewith for your consideration, Voucher No. 454 in favour of University St. Joseph, for the amount of $11.28. Mr. F.J. Hudson, Acting Indian Agent, Richibucto, N.B.

The account for $8.00 was submitted to us under cover of the former Agent's letter dated June 21, 1940, and, in a letter dated June 25, 1940, he was advised that, as the full amount promised for this boy's tuition had already been paid, the Department was not prepared to consider paying an additional $8.00. Re: Miss. Florence Knockwood, Fort Folly Reserve, N.B.
Educational Training.

This Agency office is in receipt of an application from Miss. Florence Knockwood, an Indian girl of the Fort Folly Reservation, for assistance in taking a business course. This girl who is 17 years old, has completed grade VIII and had spent some time in grade IX, when she left school in March 1947.

Two schools have been contacted for information regarding the business course they offer and both are reluctant to accept pupils with less than grade X training. However, one of them, the Robinson Business College at Moncton, N.B., is willing to take Miss. Knockwood, at any time on trial. This is not recommended because it is not felt that she would be able to master the course nor would it be desirable to send this girl to study where living accommodation would have to be found outside the school. It would be preferable to assist Miss. Knockwood to complete grades IX and X at the Superior School at Dorchester, N.B., which she attended formerly.

Miss. Knockwood, has expressed the wish to attend the Robinson Business College, Moncton, N.B., and a suggestion that she return to the Dorchester Superior School in order to complete grades IX and X will not be well received by herself or by her father and no doubt will result in correspondence directly with the Indian Affairs Branch. Some guidance in the matter would be appreciated.

E.J. Blakey
(E. J. Blakey,) Supt.,
N.B. Northeastern Indian Agency.

Re: Fuel for the Saint Mary's and Woodstock Indian Schools

Enclosed you will find a tender which I obtained from Edward T. Moran regarding an oil burner for the Saint Mary's Indian School, also one for the Woodstock Indian School. Moran has burners on hand at the present time and the British American Oil Co. stated they will supply oil for these schools at 17½¢ per gallon (subject to change in price).

Considerable difficulty has been experienced in the Devon School in getting a janitor, also in the Woodstock School. In the latter place a large quantity of wood has to be piled out of doors as the storing capacity in the basement is very small and the Indians steal a considerable amount of the wood outside.

If finances would warrant it I would recommend that oil burners be placed in both the Saint Mary's and Woodstock Schools.

I would have requested permission to purchase these oil burners at an earlier date but it was only yesterday that the local dealer of the British American Oil Co. could assure me furnace oil would be available. May I hear from you regarding these at an early date.

Wood is available at $20.00 per cord.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

RJB/MDG
Ottawa, January 29, 1948.

E. J. Whalen,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.

Re: Cutting of Fuel Wood for Schools and Cutting of Telephone Poles for Eskasoni

I wish to inform you that in the course of the next few days you will receive two cheques, one for $600.00 from Administration Vote, to be used for the cutting of telephone poles which will be shipped to Eskasoni after the break-up next spring, and one for $250.00 to pay for the cutting of hardwood, at $4.00 per cord, for next year's heating of the Woodstock and Kingsclear schools.

Note, the poles and the wood should be cut and yarded so that after the snow disappears the truck can be used to transport the poles to the ear and the wood to the schools concerned.

I am sorry that additional funds are not available in the present fiscal year's estimates to make it possible to authorize you to cut a quantity of cedar for the manufacture of shingles. As soon as our new estimates have been approved, and if money is made available in time, cedar for shingles could be cut during the month of April or early in May.

If the amount of money sent to you is more than is required for the cutting of poles and wood, then you have authority to use the balance for the cutting of cedar for the shingle mill. While the amount being forwarded to you is not very large, it will give you an opportunity to provide some employment for those able-bodied Indians who are now out of work.

During my last visit to your Agency, I discussed with you the advisability of sending in a voucher in favour of the Receiver General, to be credited to Welfare Vote, for
the payment of the number of shingles required to shingle the roof of the barn, at $7.00 per 1000. It is suggested that you submit such a voucher for 20,000 or 25,000 shingles, to Miss Walton who is in charge of the Administration Vote for the construction of buildings, and transfer the amount to the Welfare Vote which I hope will be returned to you so that you can cut an additional quantity of cedar for next year's shingle mill operation.

J. E. Morris,
Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Prince William, R.R.#2, dated April 13, 1948.

The above numbered voucher in favour of Walden L. Scott is for 2' furnace wood purchased for the Woodstock Indian Day School.

It cost about twice as much to heat the Woodstock School this year, as I had planned, and also twice as much as other years. Although Ray Hall appeared to be doing his best to supply this school with wood, the quality and quantity which he purchased locally was everything but satisfactory.

When I visited the Woodstock School the first week in March, and saw such a small amount of wood after having been supplied with so much, I immediately told Mr. Hall to discontinue supplying wood to this school.

On my way from Woodstock I located three cords of nice old growth maple, beech, and yellow birch, which I purchased. I then had Departmental Truck No. 1105 haul this wood to the Woodstock School.

I would recommend that an oil burner be purchased for this school, as the Indians steal the wood from the school. Last year authority was granted to purchase an oil burner, but no supply of oil could be obtained at that time. Recently, while talking to the Imperial Oil dealer in Woodstock, he informed me that he thought he could supply oil for the school another year, and said he would be certain after May 1.

Edward J. Whalen,

FILE ........................................ VOLUME .........................
Dear Sir:

Blanche Thomas, daughter of Michael Thomas, age 18, from P.E.I. Reservation, is now living with her grandfather, Isaac Peters at Eureka, about 17 miles from here. The reason she came to this province is as follows: When she was in P.E.I., she had to walk 2 miles to go to school and she was advised by a doctor to stop school because she is crippled and the distance she had to walk would finally hurt her crippled leg. Wishing to continue her studies, she came to live with her grandfather at Eureka whose house is alongside the schoolhouse. She is now in Grade X. Her difficulty is that the books she had in P.E.I. are not those used in this province. She needs the four following books if she is to continue her studies at Eureka:

1. Canadian Book of Prose and Verse - Book IV
2. History of England by Carrington and Hampden Jackson
3. French Grammar by Dondo
4. Essential Latin for Grade X.

As she is not able to buy them herself, she has asked me to ask the Department if it could procure them for her. If you have not these books in stock, with your permission, I could buy them in New Glasgow. The total cost would probably be around $5.00.

As this case seems to be a deserving one, I recommend that the Department either lend or buy the above named books for this Indian girl.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. E. Chiasson,
Indian agent.
Ottawa,
January 21, 1941.

EXD.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant with reference to Blanche Thomas and in view of your recommendation you may expend an amount of $5.00 for the purchase of the books that she requires.

For your information I may say that this girl has been attending school for several years past at Charlottetown, P.E.I., and the Department has been paying for her tuition and in addition paid the St. Joseph's Convent, Charlottetown, for her midday meal. Last May we found that she was 18 years of age and instructions were issued to the effect that no further grant could be allowed for her after the end of June, 1940.

The books are now being authorized but it should be distinctly understood by all parties concerned that this is the last amount the Department is prepared to pay for the education of this girl. If there is any charge for tuition at the school which she is now attending this Department will not be responsible for it.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. E. Chiasson,
Indian Agent,
Thorburn, N.S.

Dear Sir:

In answer to your letter dated May 30th, file no. 103-57 re the Thomas family, I may say that this family lives about a mile and a quarter out of Charlottetown. They have been attending St. Joseph's Convent prior to my appointment. Their tuition and dinner has been paid for by the Department since that time and in your letter here-to referred to you have cancelled the grant of that of Rachael and Blanche who are past the school age. I therefore forwarded the accounts from the Convent for meals as usual by voucher 1253 referred to in your recent letter dated Feb. 18th., file no. 103-57.

This family is considered very bright in School and one of them (Rachael), 20 yrs. of age is now completing a Business Course at the Union Commercial College in Charlottetown.

THE COMMISSIONER:

The most noticeable situation, and one that it is felt should be remedied, is that of the large number of children who are not attending school, although they are the proper age. There are at least 12 or 15 children who are either not going to school at all, or for only a few weeks a year. Another point is that the Indian Children are not medically examined for tuberculosis, and the Lowbush School Committee are reluctant to encourage their attendance. It is suggested that this matter be studied by the Indian Affairs Branch, as the situation is deplorable, and should be remedied at the earliest moment.

In summing up the entire report it would seem that the Indian Agent's complaint as regards liquor activities amongst the Lowbush Indians has been explained and that the source of supply is at Cochrane, Ont., and not at Lowbush. This would seem to be substantiated by the fact that all these Indian homes were visited on the 25-9-48 without any trace of intoxicants being found and also by the fact that one Indian was arrested at Cochrane, Ont., the following date when about to leave by train on the return trip to the settlement and in possession of certain liquors which it was definitely ascertained had been purchased in Cochrane, as regards the gasoline regulations, according to Mr. L. Dent, the Game and Fisheries Overseer, certain seizures were made of gasoline from these Indians and it would seem that the seizures were quite justified. The matter of unregistered firearms was very carefully gone into and in the opinion of the writer, they are very few, if any, unregistered weapons amongst these Indians. I might mention that the Game Overseer visits these Indians quite frequently, from Cochrane, Ontario and that he has registered all the Indians' weapons himself. The condition most noticeable amongst these Indians and one which should be remedied is that of the "Indian children not attending school." The matter of the liquor activities is being attended to day by day by the various police forces at Cochrane, Ontario but the matter of the children would not appear to be one for the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa to decide.

Cranney and in the opinion of the writer, it is a situation which should be remedied. Namely, it was noticed that there were a large number of Indian children of school age running about the banks of the river and very obviously not attending school regularly. This matter was gone into quite thoroughly when it was ascertained that a number of the Indian children of that settlement do not attend school at all and that the ones who do attend, average possibly six weeks out of the entire season; The balance of the time they are either playing about the bush at Lowbush or away up the river with their parents. There is a school at Lowbush, in close proximity to this Indian settlement and no outward reason why these children should not be attending school and attending regularly.

At present there are 14 white children attending the Lowbush school and but three Indians. A check in the settlement reveals that the following Indians had children of school age who are not attending:

| NAME          | NUMBER OF SCHOOL AGE |
|---------------|----------------------|
| Alec Black    | three children       |
| Albert Biederman | "                   |
| David Black   | two                  |
| John Charlebois | "                   |
| Pete Diamond  | Children of age but number not ascertained |

There would appear to be no good reason why all of the above mentioned children should not be attending school and attending regularly. However, it would seem that they have never attended regularly and no doubt will as long as they live the life they are living at present. By that it is meant that when the parents are at Lowbush, by enforcing the provisions of Sec. 10 Sub-section 4 of the Indian Act, they could be kept at school a reasonable length of the time they reside at Lowbush. However, the parents spent the majority of their time in some camp up the river and when they move up there they are in the habit of
taking the children along with them with the result that the children are taken out of school and at a time like that it would be impossible to attempt to enforce Sec. 10(4) of the Indian Act. In the opinion of the writer, this situation as regards the Indian children at Lowbush in a most unfortunate one and one that should be remedied and that as soon as possible. It is difficult to suggest just how the situation could be remedied except of course, if the Department would step in and place all these Indian Children of school age in one of the various Indian Residential Schools. That is, in the writer's opinion, the only way that these children will ever get an education. To leave them at Lowbush and endeavour to enforce the Indian Act would appear to be out of the question as the parent AS THE PARENTS are away too much of the time.

10. Another complaint, heard while at Lowbush was one received from a member of the Lowbush School Committee and that being that all Indian children, before being admitted to the local School should be medically examined and be able to produce a certificate to that effect. The reason given for this complaint being that Tuberculosis is quite prevalent amongst these Indians and that to protect the other children of the school, each child should be forced to undergo a strict medical examination before being admitted to the school.

Dear Sir,

Re Josephine Polson - age 13 - daughter of Charlie Polson - Temiskamingue Indians.

This Indian fall, arranged to provide at Amos, Que., Pensionat Ste-Marie, education for his daughter; this at a cost of $19.50 per month. At the time, since and again today, demanded assistance in the form of a monthly allowance, I understand $10.00 per month, would be satisfactory, the difference he could meet, from his revenue, work or trapping.

These Polsons originated from Temiskamingue, trapped all their lives north of La Sarre, Que., they have their camps located near Otter Lake, a distance of about 40 miles, from nearest railway point. This man's father Philip together with his family developed to take care of themselves during summer months, a fair farm, they cultivate land, on scale to permit them a fair living, when they can secure a little cash from the sale of their furs, settlers and white trappers are closing in on them more and more every year. These Polsons they are Indians, but outstanding, they stand up very well to the average white settlers, as regard mode of living etc., Philip & Charlie have learned to read and write more or less by themselves able to speak English and French, their wives also speak English, both are good housekeepers.

Considering that these Polsons, are not the "bush type" made actual efforts on their own, to improve and change their living habits, they have no other means to provide this child with education except placing her at a boarding school, considering the cost, I recommend same to your attention, in this case I feel if assistance could be granted, it would be a sound investment.

Your obedient servant,

Monsieur,

Nous sommes heureuses de vous informer que Mlle Joséphine Polson a atteint un développement intellectuel suffisant pour suivre avec profit, en la prochaine année scolaire, la sixième année du cours des études primaires. La langue française lui devient familière peu à peu quoiqu'elle ait plus de facilité pour la langue anglaise. Nous nous proposons, tout en la maintenant au cours régulier, de lui conseiller des cours spéciaux de dessin à notre studio, elle manifeste une certaine facilité pour cet art et nous estimons qu'il contribuera largement à sa culture générale; ce lui sera de plus un précieux instrument quand elle entreprendra les études du cours d'enseignement ménager auquel jusqu'à présent nous l'avons crue destinée.

Nous connaissons trop votre sollicitude à l'égard de cette étudiante pour douter des efforts que vous déploierez en vue de la maintenir aux études.

Nous vous remercions, Monsieur, de tout le bien que vous avez assuré à Mlle Polson et vous prions de croire en notre religieuse considération.

Amos, July 22, 1945.

Sir:

We are pleased to inform you that Miss Joséphine Polson has reached an intellectual development which will allow her to take advantage in her next school year of the 6th year of the primary course. She is becoming gradually familiar with the French language although she speaks English more easily. We were planning, while continuing the regular studies, to suggest for her special drawing lessons at our studio. She shows a certain aptitude for this art, and we feel that it will contribute considerably to her general development. It should prove quite helpful when she begins her domestic art course to which we believe she is destined.

It would be unfortunate if she were not to return to the school. It is a very interesting experience for us to promote the education of a child of her race. We are aware of your solicitude for this student and have no doubt that you wish her to continue her studies.

November 10th, 1946

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: L'Orphelinat du Sacre Coeur - La Taque, Que.

I must refer you to yours File No. 103-74, August 1st, 1945, as regard 4 children provided at this institution, when at La Taque on October 8th, 1946, the Superior demanded that we consider allowing a rate of $18.00 per month, based on present cost of food and other supplies, also cost of help.

These 4 children prior to admission to this institution were costing the Department a great deal with next to no outlook for betterment, so they were transferred, since the mother of the Eraseups has paid positively no attention to them, the father has disappeared, the children have improved and when seen on October 8th., the prospect are, they may turn out to be normal Indians later, both are very bright. The others, are doing extremely well, and both it is question of keeping at an orphanage, if placed with other Indians, they would in no time spend their time at the hospital instead out and would cost a great deal. Elizabeth was treated at a Sanatorium for a long period, Philomena was in and out of the hospital all the time, hasn't been sick since taken care at the orphanage.

I understand the present rate for whites is $18.00, considering this and present conditions of these Indian children, I recommend that their request be granted,

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 14 November 1946.

Mr. H. Lariviere, Indian Agent,
AMOS, Quebec.

We have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to the four Indian children who are enrolled at L'Orphelinat du Sacre Coeur, La Tuque, Quebec.

The rate requested is higher than we allow for each pupil at any of our Indian Residential Schools.

It has been decided to allow the increased amount of $18.00 a month for each of the four children until June 30, 1947. About that time you should communicate with us again and arrangements will be made to transfer them to one of our regular Indian residential schools. If we had accommodation at any of these schools at the present time, we would transfer them immediately but as all of them have a full enrolment, the transfer will have to be delayed until next June.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Your No. 103-74 (W.T. I.)

November 14th, 1946

I must refer you to this letter, as regard the 4 children presently at La Tuque.

I note it is your intention to transfer them to an Indian residential school; particularly in the case of Philomene Sagamah and Elizabeth Boucher, both are from Weymontachie, near La Tuque, they see other Indians often, etc., my personal opinion is, these two in particular will be better off at La Tuque, as regard the Brascoops, their mother has given them up, briefly they are ours for ever, the father has disappeared no indications whatsoever as to his whereabouts, in any event it is better for all concerned that he did give up like, transferring outside of the District other Indians I feel will accept that, their grandparents are not interested in them and they are the poorest types of primitive Indians, very little good in them.

Please advise in late June, of your wishes.

H. Lariviere - Indian Agent.

P.S. All these children are doing fair in school, Elizabeth Boucher very satisfactory, all have no place to go so in summer, they must remain at orphanage.

Ottawa, August 5th, 1947.

Mr. J.R. Lamothe, Indian Agent,
Notre Dame du Nord, P.Q.

We have received a letter from the principal of the Institut Francais Evangelique, Pointe-aux-Trembles, Que., in which he states that Mr. Delphis Tolley of Clova, Que., has applied to that institution for the admission of his daughter Therese Tolley. On the application form he states that he is a Catholic; the Institut Francais Evangelique is operated under the auspices of the United Church of Canada.

In his letter the principal of Institut Francais Evangelique states that Tolley requested him to refer to the Department for payment of her tuition. In view of sub-section 2 of section 10 of the Indian Act, it has not been the practice of the Department to allow a grant when an Indian child is being sent to a school operated under different religious auspices from her own.

We have been paying tuition fees for Therese Tolley who has been attending the school at Clova. I understand that she is 13 years of age but we do not know what grade she has reached.

Please let me know what your opinion is on the father's request.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Her place is at home, under supervision of parents, if they cannot do so through her stubbornness and activities they should refer the matter to the Provincial Police.

Her older sister, gave birth to an illegitimate child I understand again an expectant mother and last year it was revealed that Therese was the vicious type and committed minor crimes when at the hospital at La Tuque, such as stealing from patients.

I cannot understand how Dolphis Tolley, happened to make application through Institution mentioned, they are catholic and other main church activities at Clova are conducted by the anglicans. From the time Dolphis Tolley demanded assistance, for her last year, when he found out she was being checked at the hospital he caused difficulties, I cannot understand his unusual interest in this child and the negligence in general on other members of his family. More The Tolleys are making at the present good money, above what I earn myself.

Des Indiens réclament la ville de Cornwall

Cornwall, Ont. le (C.P.) — Les Indiens de la Confédération des Six Nations, s'appuyant sur une ancienne entente de l'origine coloniale, demandent une équitable proportion du produit des taxes municipales comme loyer, car disent-ils, cette ville de 15.000 habitants leur appartenait.

La Confédération des Six Nations réclame une vaste étendue de territoire, y compris la ville de Cornwall ainsi qu'une longueur de six milles de terrain le long du Saint-Laurent qui aurait été autrefois destiné à une réserve indienne.

Peter-L. Johnson, de Saint-Régis, P.Q., assistant du grand chef de la Confédération, doit se rendre à Ottawa, pour y soutenir les droits et réclamations des Indiens.

Les Indiens prétendent, de plus, que les nombreuses îles du Saint-Laurent entre Prescott et Lachine, sur une longueur d'environ 70 milles, leur appartiennent, de même qu'une étendue de terrain de 20.000 acres dans le comté de Huntingdon, P.Q.

This year Miss Alice Trapp was on the hospital staff as a regular employee.

October 21, 1948.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Amos, Que.

We have your letter of the 14th instant enclosing application for tuition grants for the following:

Charlotte Gull
Charlotte Blacksmith
Annie Dube
Delima Flamand

If you refer to official letter of August 12th you will note that we promised to allow a grant of $40.00 for each of the four Indian girls for a period of nine months during the academic year 1948-49.

However, it is noted from the application form that only $30.00 from the appropriation for Indian Education is required for Charlotte Gull.

We are, therefore, prepared to allow an amount of $40.00 a month for a period of nine months during the academic year 1948-49, for the last three named girls mentioned above, but only $30.00 a month for nine months for Charlotte Gull.

The amounts authorized in this letter will be paid from the appropriation for Indian Education. This Division has no authority to authorize funds from the Welfare appropriation.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
Since 1946, in some ways we had difficulties to secure cover, that is payment for the training of these girls, just at present, we have 4 girls at La Tuque, one, Charlotte Gull, Education agreed at first to pay in full the $40.00 per month, but the fact that last year $30.00 was paid by Education and $10.00 by Welfare they have now declined to pay the $10.00 in her case, which means we are $10.00 short for period of training, that is for 9 months at $10.00 per month.

Authority would be appreciated to cover, if it cannot be granted, this Indian girl, considered very suitable will have to return home, this is her second year and starting to give us what we expect from her, these girls need to be trained for 3 years, to give satisfactory results.

H. Lariviere - Supt. Indian Agency.
Attention: Welfare Division

Re: Letter from Education No. 42074-3 (E1) dated October 21st, 1948, and Letter 10374 (E1) August 12th, 1948.

This year considering the success we had on training what appeared the most intelligent Indian girls, to act as interpreters and assistants to nurses in the field, La Tuque Hospital, agreed to undertake training 4 girls, at $40.00 per month each, to select these girls, it is still in some ways complicated, however this is the Agency responsibility and troubles.

This idea, started in 1945, after discussing in Ottawa with Dr. P.E. Moore, now Director I.H.S., in order to get results from our Medical Field Services, in 1946 we could get only one girl who in our opinion would stand up and so on, Miss. Trapper, for her training at the time, I was advised Education would pay $20.00 per month and Welfare $10.00, that is $40.00 per month which was the agreed price with the hospital.

With Miss. Trapper, we increased our preventive measures, briefly we got out of it, more work from the nurses and more an improved understanding of things, from the part of the natives, briefly results are, all the various divisions are getting an improvement out of it; one point which I consider very important improved confidence from the part of the natives, which prepares the ground for education, hygiene and so on, probably at the start the Medical got out of it the most, however they paid for all the summer expenses for these girls and salary. To-day I estimate Welfare is getting a good share and Education with time will get an equal share, through them the natives start to realize that some education is good.

The idea in general about training and employing these girls, with nurses was to make a definite start to improve these natives, in some cases most primitive and without the aid of the most intelligent Indians, progress is too slow to make much headway.

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Training of Nurses' Aides for the Abitibi Agency

In line with the wishes of Church authorities as expressed to the Parliamentary Committee on the subject of medical and nursing services to the Indians, it would be well, I think, to invite Mr. Superintendent Lariviere's attention to the desirability of assigning nurses and nurses' aides to the larger bands with due regard for religious affiliation. In the case of the large bands at Mistassini and Waswanipi, it seems to be difficult to get nursing personnel of Protestant affiliation, or to recruit and train under Protestant auspices of an adequate nature new personnel. It seems to me that to send girls who are sketchily schooled in the academic and religious fields, to a training institution which might tax their mental capacity and confuse their religious patterns, would likely produce an instability that would become evident sooner or later and result in casualties during training or in later service. A review of the cases mentioned on this file seems to support this opinion.

I discussed the matter briefly with Dr. Leroux who admitted that we have not available the ideal method of getting needed personnel. He thinks that when the Moose Factory hospital has been completed, some of these nurses' aides may be trained there. That does not, however, solve the problem of their required pre-hospital schooling. It would seem that more girls from the Abitibi area should be directed at an earlier age to appropriate residential schools. At present Spanish and Moose Fort are the most accessible and I would suggest that their quotas for the Abitibi agency be increased.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Dear Canon Cook:

Miss Katherine Gull - Waswanipi Band

We have a suggestion from Bishop Renison that this girl be assisted to train as a nurse or teacher.

It is suggested that this girl be sent to Moose Factory for a year's apprenticeship to be served in your hospital and residential school. If at the end of that time she shows the necessary progress, aptitude, and interest she will be considered for employment in the Government hospital there. As far as teaching is concerned it has yet to be demonstrated that Miss Gull's abilities lie in this field and she should not be entrusted with the usual duties of a teacher in a residential school.

The suggested arrangement between your administration and this Department is that you should provide room and board and training under qualified instructors and the Department will pay the girl's transportation from Waswanipi to Moose Factory and return and the sum of $30 a month to the hospital matron of which she shall pay to the girl $10 a month as pocket money. The monthly payments are to be claimed quarterly through our Superintendent at Amos, Que. The agreement may be terminated by either party after a month's notice.

We are writing to the girl to determine whether she will accept this offer of room and board, training, and $10 a month.

I think that the best place for you to go is Moose Factory. There is a small hospital at Moose Factory and there is a boarding school near it. You would have some time in which to study and to do things which you like to do in your spare time, but you would have to keep the rules that the hospital and the school make for people who work there.

Further to yours, as regard Indian girl Katherine Gull, as soon we hear from her, will take necessary action, if necessary to make a charter trip, will advise you, at this time or year traffic in that district is just about nil, the Gulls very likely are now at Lake Opawica.

Dear Sir:

I just thought I would drop a few lines to you as we are in the best of health.

And now we are having today, as I am telling you that I had a letter from Philip Philen Chief Education Division of Moose Factory he said that he could give me a job in the school or hospital. But that is to little a month ago. This is all I wanted to say.

I will close for now.

Best regards to you.

Yours Truly,

Katherine Gull.

To The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa

Re: Kathleen Gull - Waswanipi Band
Attention: Education Division

Herewith original letter from Miss. Gull, which speaks for itself.

This time she offers as the excuse not enough pay $10.00 per month, she is familiar with the plan for the training of other girls, 3 months work was in my opinion always about her limit.

H. Lariviere - Supt Indian Agency.
October 6th, 1949.

Mr. H. Lariviere,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Amos, P.Q.

Re: Katherine Gull
Your File 25-8

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, you may inform Miss Gull that we are not prepared to allow her more than $10.00 a month if she accepts the offer outlined in our letter of September 16th.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
